name: Moo Maid
description:
Approximately 11 x 14 inches or 28 x 35.5 cm. Exceptionally clean, perfect rendering of this underwater whimsical scene, the bubbles and everything are very nice. This 2010 painting is by Stewart Moskowitz, creator of American Rabbit, Dinky Dinos, etc. Stapled on the sides, this small canvas is on regular stretcher bars an inch and a half wide so it's very sturdy.

This mermaid... um, moo-maid, is a combination of brush and airbrush. There aren't a lot of brush painted pictures by Stu (at this moment most paintings in this store are brush painted, but most of his work is largely or entirely airbrushed).

name: Smooth Sailing
description:
Approximately 48 x 33 inches or 122 x 84 cm. This is a signed original 2008 painting by Stewart Moskowitz, creator of American Rabbit, Dinky Dinos, etc. This whimsical sailfish ship, painted on stretched canvas in the classic Moskowitz airbrush style, is similar to a popular image he first painted some years ago. Stu sometimes enjoys painting a variation on an old design or he makes one as a commissioned piece, and he's painted about five of this particular design, mostly as commissions I think. It's a pretty good guess that the last one is more finely executed than the first one in these situations, and that has been my observation. Stu's ability with color and line has never stopped improving. So this is likely the best Smooth Sailing, and also likely the last one since Stu only occasionally paints in the "old" style today and he is increasingly busy with other work.

This large canvas was removed from its frame by the artist who then re-stretched it on the same frame with a backing of luan board permanently under the canvas. This is for added protection during transit.

name: Save the Whales
description:
Approximately 13 x 16 inches or 33 x 41 cm. This loosely "sketched" re-rendering of a popular Moskowitz poster is a signed original 2010 painting by Stewart Moskowitz. The canvas is stretched over an old picture frame (I think it's oak) and is stapled on the sides, and since the frame has a rounded edge, the picture will look best in a frame or matte that overlaps the edge by most of an inch (2 or 3 cm). By "rounded edge" I mean the carved contour of the frame, which is not warped or off-square although the photo makes it look that way. Or you could leave it with no frame, but since the outer margin has some pencil markings (which barely show in the photo) I think it would look best framed.

This whimsical small canvas is brush painted, no airbrush. There aren't a lot of brush painted pictures by Stu (at this moment most paintings in this store are brush painted, but most of his work is largely or entirely airbrushed).
